data.title: 167 Beautiful Italian Girl Names With Detailed Meanings
data.meta_description: Find a curated collection of Italian girl names, each brimming with history and significance. We've ensured each name is unique, and have organized them into practical categories.
data.text:
In this article, youâ€™ll find a carefully curated collection of Italian girl names, each brimming with history and significance.

Iâ€™ve crafted a range of categories to make your selection journey more meaningful and intuitive.

In a hurry? Click on a link to jump straight to the relevant section!

Most Popular Names (in Italy) â€“ per official Italian Institute for Statistics data. We included this section as the last one.

Traditional names â€“ they have stood the test of time and still sound relevant today.

Unique and uncommon â€“ names unconventional in modern times, making them unique choices for someone seeking a distinct Italian name for a girl.

Royal or Aristocratic connotations â€“ perfect for those who appreciate Italian heritage with royal or aristocratic significance.

Badass names â€“ names that exude strength, determination, and resilience. They combine Italian heritage with a sense of grit and resilience.

Elegant and Beautiful â€“ names are imbued with grace, charm, and timeless beauty.

Religious or Spiritual Names â€“ for families wishing to honor their faith and beliefs.

Italian-American â€“ names that derive from traditional Italian names but have adaptations or are influenced by popular American naming trends.

Names that mean Love â€“ Italian female names with strong connotations of love, affection, and endearment in their meanings or interpretations.

Nature-inspired â€“ names directly inspired by nature, along with those that are more symbolic in nature, representing elements of the natural world or natural phenomena.

Virtue-inspired â€“ Italian names for females that evoke virtues. Some directly tied to virtues, others more symbolic, representing a desired quality or attribute for the bearer.

Joy or Happiness-inspired â€“ names that convey joy, delight, or happiness.

Star or moon-inspired â€“ including names that carry celestial or heavenly connotations.

Musical-inspired â€“ names that draw from musical terms and aspects.

Why not alphabetical order?: After some discussion, we decided that it doesnâ€™t make much sense to list all the names from A to Z, because other sites already did it well enough (e.g. Momjunction.com, here).

Italian Female Names with Meanings

Traditional / Vintage Names

Hereâ€™s a list of traditional, old, vintage, and otherwise old-fashioned Italian female names, along with concise meanings:

Adelina â€“ Derived from the word â€œnoble,â€ it signifies someone who is honorable and of noble lineage.

Alessandra â€“ A variation of Alexander, it represents someone who is a protector or defender of mankind.

Angelica â€“ Resonating with the essence of an angel, this name symbolizes an angelic messenger or someone like an angel.

Antonella â€“ An endearing form of Antonia, it indicates someone beyond praise or highly commendable.

Bianca â€“ Rooted in the Italian word for white, this name signifies purity, clarity, and innocence.

Camilla â€“ Of Latin origin, it represents a young ceremonial attendant and implies someone noble and free-born.

Caterina â€“ An Italian variant of Katherine, it symbolizes pureness and clarity of character.

Chiara â€“ Derived from the Latin â€œClarus,â€ it signifies someone clear, bright, and luminous.

Cristina â€“ An Italian form of Christina, it embodies one who follows Christ.

Daniela â€“ The female counterpart of Daniel, it symbolizes one who believes that â€œGod is my judge.â€

Elisabetta â€“ An Italian version of Elizabeth, suggesting that Godâ€™s promise is unbreakable and steadfast.

Emilia â€“ Related to the Roman family name Aemilius, it implies ambition and industrious nature.

Francesca â€“ The female form of Francesco, reflecting one who is free or from France.

Gabriella â€“ An Italian form of Gabrielle, suggesting Godâ€™s unwavering strength.

Gemma â€“ Directly taken from the Italian word for gem, symbolizing something or someone precious.

Giovanna â€“ Italian female form of John, denoting Godâ€™s gracious gift.

Giulia â€“ A variant of Julia, signifying someone youthful with soft and downy characteristics.

Graziella â€“ A diminutive of Grazia, indicating someone graceful or possessing charm.

Isabella â€“ A form of Elizabeth, echoing the idea of Godâ€™s unyielding promise.

Liliana â€“ Deriving from the Latin word for lily, it symbolizes purity, beauty, and renewal.

Lucia â€“ Coming from the Latin â€œluxâ€ meaning light, it denotes illumination or one who brings light.

Margherita â€“ Italian form of Margaret, signifying a daisy or pearl, representing purity and preciousness.

Marianna â€“ A combination of Maria and Anna, it embodies the bitter grace of both.

Natalia â€“ Rooted in the Latin â€œNatalis,â€ it signifies birth, particularly celebrating Christâ€™s birth or Christmas Day.

Orabella â€“ A fusion of Italian words meaning â€œgoldenâ€ and â€œbeautiful,â€ symbolizing radiant beauty.

Raffaella â€“ Emphasizing Godâ€™s healing powers, a name for someone perceived as a healer or protector.

Rosa â€“ Directly referencing the rose flower, itâ€™s a symbol of beauty, love, and grace.

Serafina â€“ Originating from the biblical seraphs, it signifies one who is fiery, ardent, or angelic.

Silvia â€“ From Latin roots, it denotes someone from the forest or woodlands.

Stefania â€“ Italian female form of Stephen, signifying someone who is crowned or victorious.

Teresa â€“ With uncertain origins, itâ€™s believed to symbolize someone who reaps, referencing a harvester.

Valentina â€“ Deriving from the word â€œvalor,â€ it signifies someone strong, vigorous, and powerful.

Viviana â€“ Coming from the Latin â€œvivus,â€ it symbolizes someone alive, lively, and full of life.

Unique and Uncommon

Allegra â€“ Meaning â€œjoyfulâ€ or â€œlively,â€ itâ€™s derived from the musical term that signifies a brisk tempo.

Beatrice â€“ Originating from Latin, it signifies one who brings happiness or blessings.

Carlotta â€“ The Italian version of Charlotte, it means â€œfree womanâ€ or â€œpetite.â€

Delfina â€“ Meaning â€œdolphin,â€ itâ€™s often associated with the grace and playfulness of the marine creature.

Elettra â€“ Derived from the Greek mythological figure Electra, it means â€œshiningâ€ or â€œbright.â€

Fiorenza â€“ An older Italian name, meaning â€œfloweringâ€ or â€œblossoming,â€ emphasizing blooming or growth.

Giordana â€“ Female form of Giordano, it means â€œdescendâ€ or is related to the Jordan River.

Ludovica â€“ The female counterpart of Ludovico, it signifies a renowned warrior.

Mirella â€“ Deriving from the name Mireille, it means â€œto admireâ€ or â€œwonderful.â€

Nicoletta â€“ A diminutive form of Nicole, it signifies victory of the people.

Ottavia â€“ Related to the number eight, it traditionally represents someone born eighth.

Priscilla â€“ Meaning â€œancientâ€ or â€œvenerable,â€ it denotes someone with wisdom or ageless beauty.

Quiteria â€“ Originating from the Latin â€œquietus,â€ it signifies tranquility or peacefulness.

Renata â€“ Derived from the Latin word for â€œborn again,â€ it implies renewal or rebirth.

Sabrina â€“ Related to the River Severn in Wales, its meaning is â€œboundary.â€

Tiziana â€“ Derived from the ancient Roman family name Titius, the exact meaning is uncertain but might relate to giants.

Umbriana â€“ Named after the Italian region Umbria, it embodies the beauty and essence of the area.

Vittoria â€“ Italian form of Victoria, it signifies triumph or a victorious one.

Zita â€“ Often used to refer to a young girl or maiden in Tuscany, its origin might be Hungarian meaning â€œgirl.â€

Celestina â€“ Derived from the Latin â€œcaelestis,â€ it signifies â€œheavenlyâ€ or â€œof the skies.â€

Royal or Aristocratic Connotations

Regina â€“ Meaning â€œqueen.â€

Reina â€“ A variant of Regina, also meaning â€œqueen.â€

Isabella â€“ Historically significant name with several queens named Isabella, it means â€œpledged to God.â€

Adelaide â€“ A royal name that means â€œnoble natured.â€

Alessandra â€“ The feminine form of Alessandro, meaning â€œdefender of the people.â€ Reminiscent of nobilityâ€™s protective role.

Bianca â€“ Named popular among royalty, meaning â€œwhiteâ€ or â€œfair.â€

Carlotta â€“ Italian version of Charlotte, a queenly name meaning â€œfree woman.â€

Caterina â€“ An Italian form of Katherine, which has been a name of many queens. It means â€œpure.â€

Eleonora â€“ A name with royal connotations, meaning â€œshining lightâ€ or â€œsun ray.â€

Federica â€“ Feminine form of Federico, meaning â€œpeaceful ruler.â€

Lucrezia â€“ A historical name tied to the noble Borgia family, meaning â€œprofitâ€ or â€œwealth.â€

Margherita â€“ Meaning â€œpearl.â€ Several queens across history had this name.

Vittoria â€“ Italian form of Victoria, meaning â€œvictory.â€ Queen Victoria is the most famed bearer of the name.

Ludovica â€“ The female form of Ludovico, meaning â€œfamous in battle,â€ implying nobility and strength.

Beatrice â€“ Meaning â€œbringer of joy.â€ Several royals and aristocrats in history have carried this name.

Rachele â€“ While it means â€œewe,â€ this name has been borne by queens and princesses in history.

Valentina â€“ Meaning â€œstrong, vigorous.â€ Itâ€™s a name with both royal and saintly connotations.

Sofia â€“ Meaning â€œwisdom.â€ Queen Sofia of Spain is a contemporary bearer.

Diana â€“ Meaning â€œdivine.â€ The name of the beloved Princess Diana.

Arianna â€“ Meaning â€œmost holy.â€ While not strictly royal, it has an aristocratic sound.

Francesca â€“ Meaning â€œfree one.â€ The name exudes an air of aristocracy.

Leonora â€“ A variation of Eleonora, meaning â€œlight.â€ It has a noble and royal connotation.

Ginevra â€“ The Italian form of Guinevere, which means â€œwhite phantom.â€ Queen Guinevere was the legendary queen of King Arthur.

â€œbadassâ€ names

Valeria â€“ Meaning â€œstrength, valor.â€ Derived from the Latin â€œvalereâ€ (to be strong).

Battista â€“ Meaning â€œbaptist.â€ A name with strong religious connotations and a fierce sound.

Brigida â€“ Derived from the Celtic â€œbrighâ€ which means â€œpower, strength, vigor.â€

Romilda â€“ Meaning â€œfamous battle.â€ The element â€œhildâ€ stands for â€œbattle.â€

Lorita â€“ A diminutive of â€œLoredana,â€ which is believed to have origins in a title used by Venetian naval commanders.

Donatella â€“ Meaning â€œgift.â€ The name resonates with giving and generosity.

Fortunata â€“ Meaning â€œfortunate, lucky.â€ A name that suggests both strength and serendipity.

Drusilla â€“ Meaning â€œstrong.â€ A name of ancient Roman origin.

Leontina â€“ Meaning â€œlioness.â€ As the lion is often seen as the king of the jungle, a lioness is its fierce counterpart.

Marcella â€“ Feminine form of Marcellus, meaning â€œyoung warrior.â€

Rosetta â€“ Meaning â€œlittle rose.â€ Roses, while beautiful, have thorns and are often symbols of strength in adversity.

Serafina â€“ Meaning â€œardent, fiery.â€ Derived from the biblical seraphs, fiery angels.

Viliana â€“ Meaning â€œstrong-willed protector.â€

Bellatrix â€“ Meaning â€œfemale warrior.â€ A Latin name that has an undeniably strong sound to it.

Erminia â€“ A name that means â€œuniversal, whole.â€ Itâ€™s derived from the ancient Germanic element â€œerminâ€ which signifies strength.

Imelda â€“ Meaning â€œall-consuming fight.â€ A name that radiates combativeness and strength.

Natalina â€“ A variation of Natalia, meaning â€œborn on Christmas.â€ The birth of Christ carries strong connotations of renewal and resilience.

Venezia â€“ The name of the resilient city of Venice, which has withstood time and tide.

Alba â€“ Meaning â€œdawn.â€ Symbolizing a new day, resilience, and hope.

Elegant and Beautiful

Alessandra â€“ Meaning â€œdefending men.â€ A beautiful and rhythmic name reminiscent of grace and nobility.

Bianca â€“ Meaning â€œwhite, fair.â€ Evokes purity, beauty, and innocence.

Carlotta â€“ Italian form of Charlotte, meaning â€œfree woman.â€ It exudes sophistication and charm.

Elisabetta â€“ The Italian version of Elizabeth, meaning â€œGod is my oath.â€ A regal and timeless name.

Fiorenza â€“ Derived from â€œfioreâ€ meaning â€œflower.â€ It speaks of blooming beauty and grace.

Ginevra â€“ Meaning â€œjuniper tree.â€ Itâ€™s also the Italian name for Guinevere, the queen of Camelot, known for her beauty.

Isabella â€“ Meaning â€œpledged to God.â€ A name synonymous with elegance due to its royal connections.

Luciana â€“ Meaning â€œlight.â€ It radiates brightness and grace.

Mirabella â€“ Meaning â€œwonderful.â€ As the name suggests, itâ€™s beautifully melodious.

Oriana â€“ Meaning â€œdawnâ€ or â€œgolden.â€ The name is both luminous and graceful.

Renata â€“ Meaning â€œreborn.â€ The name carries a poetic, elegant feel.

Silvana â€“ Meaning â€œwildâ€ in Latin, referring to woodlands. It evokes images of natural beauty and elegance.

Tiziana â€“ An ancient name of possibly Etruscan origins. It exudes a timeless charm.

Vittoria â€“ Meaning â€œvictory.â€ An elegant name associated with success and beauty.

Zita â€“ Meaning â€œyoung girl.â€ A simple, yet regal-sounding name.

Religious or Spiritual

Maria â€“ The Italian name for the Virgin Mary. Meaning â€œwished-for childâ€ or â€œbeloved.â€

Madonna â€“ Directly translates to â€œmy ladyâ€ and often refers to the Virgin Mary in Catholicism.

Immacolata â€“ Refers to the Immaculate Conception of the Virgin Mary. Means â€œwithout stain.â€

Assunta â€“ Commemorating the Assumption of the Virgin Mary into Heaven. Meaning â€œassumed.â€

Santa â€“ Meaning â€œsaint.â€ Often used in combination with the name of a particular saint (e.g., Santa Lucia).

Lucia â€“ Saint Lucia of Syracuse is one of the earliest Christian martyrs. The name means â€œlight.â€

Chiara â€“ Named for Saint Clare of Assisi, it means â€œclear, bright.â€

Agata â€“ Saint Agatha of Sicily was a martyr and patron saint of breast cancer patients. Meaning â€œgood, honorable.â€

Francesca â€“ In honor of Saint Francis of Assisi. The feminine form means â€œfree one.â€

Caterina â€“ Saint Catherine of Siena was a theologian and patron saint of Italy. The name means â€œpure.â€

Antonia â€“ Female version of Antony; there are various saints named Antony. The name means â€œpriceless one.â€

Seraphina â€“ Deriving from the Seraphim, the highest rank of angels. Meaning â€œardentâ€ or â€œfiery.â€

Bernadetta â€“ A variation of Bernadette, relating to Saint Bernadette of Lourdes. The name means â€œbrave as a bear.â€

Cecilia â€“ Saint Cecilia is the patron saint of musicians. The name means â€œblindâ€ in Latin, symbolizing spiritual insight.

Rita â€“ Referring to Saint Rita of Cascia, known for her piety. The name means â€œpearl.â€

Italian-American

Donna â€“ An adaptation of the Italian â€œdonnaâ€ meaning â€œwomanâ€ or â€œlady.â€

Gina â€“ A short form of names ending in -gina, like â€œLuiginaâ€. Meaning â€œqueen.â€

Lisa â€“ A diminutive of Elisabetta, the Italian form of Elizabeth. Meaning â€œpledged to God.â€

Teresa â€“ Variant of the Italian â€œTeresaâ€. Meaning â€œharvesterâ€ or â€œreaper.â€

Marie â€“ A blending of the Italian â€œMariaâ€ and the English â€œMaryâ€. Meaning â€œwished-for childâ€ or â€œbeloved.â€

Nina â€“ A diminutive form often used affectionately. Means â€œlittle girlâ€ or can also be related to â€œninoâ€ meaning â€œgodâ€™s favor.â€

Angie â€“ Short form of Angela. Meaning â€œangelâ€ or â€œmessenger.â€

Tina â€“ A diminutive of names like â€œValentinaâ€ or â€œChristina.â€ It means â€œlittleâ€ or can derive meanings from the full names.

Rosie â€“ An affectionate form of Rosa or Rosaria. Meaning â€œrose.â€

Jo â€“ A diminutive used for names like â€œJoannaâ€ or â€œJosephine,â€ often blending American and Italian sounds.

Vicki â€“ Short form of Vittoria. Meaning â€œvictory.â€

Loretta â€“ A diminutive of the Italian â€œLora,â€ influenced by American naming. Meaning â€œlaurel treeâ€ or â€œsweet bay tree,â€ symbols of honor and victory.

Renee â€“ Of French origin but popular among Italian-Americans. Meaning â€œreborn.â€

Carla â€“ Female form of Carlo. Meaning â€œfree manâ€ or â€œstrong.â€

Stella â€“ Directly translates to â€œstarâ€ in Italian and has become a popular name in America.

Dina â€“ A variant of the Italian â€œAdelinaâ€ or â€œGeraldinaâ€. Meaning â€œnobleâ€ or â€œspear ruler.â€

Rita â€“ Shortened form of â€œMargaritaâ€. Meaning â€œpearl.â€

Bella â€“ Directly translates to â€œbeautifulâ€ in Italian.

Lena â€“ A diminutive of names like â€œHelenaâ€ or â€œMagdalena.â€ Meaning â€œtorchâ€ or â€œmoonlight.â€

Carmela â€“ Derived from â€œcarmeloâ€ which relates to the Virgin Mary. Meaning â€œgarden.â€

Paula â€“ Female form of Paolo. Meaning â€œsmallâ€ or â€œhumble.â€

Diana â€“ A name with ancient Roman origins. Meaning â€œheavenlyâ€ or â€œdivine.â€

Lucia â€“ Derived from the Latin â€œlux.â€ Meaning â€œlight.â€

Silvia â€“ Related to the Latin â€œsilva.â€ Meaning â€œwoodâ€ or â€œforest.â€

Francesca â€“ Female form of Francesco. Meaning â€œfree one.â€

Sofia â€“ Italian version of Sophia. Meaning â€œwisdom.â€

Nora â€“ Short form of â€œEleonoraâ€ or â€œHonoraâ€. Meaning â€œlightâ€ or â€œhonor.â€

Elena â€“ Italian form of Helen. Meaning â€œtorchâ€ or â€œmoonlight.â€

Isabella â€“ An Italian variant of â€œIsabelâ€. Meaning â€œpledged to God.â€

Gabriella â€“ Feminine form of â€œGabriele.â€ Meaning â€œGod is my strength.â€

Anita â€“ Diminutive of â€œAnnaâ€. Meaning â€œgraceâ€ or â€œfavor.â€

Monica â€“ Possibly derived from Latin â€œmonere.â€ Meaning â€œadvisor.â€

Names That Mean Love

Amara â€“ Derived from Latin â€œamÄrusâ€, meaning â€œbitterâ€ but can also be interpreted in Italian as â€œbelovedâ€ or â€œto loveâ€.

Carina â€“ Means â€œdearâ€ or â€œbelovedâ€ in Italian.

Erminia â€“ Though it traces its roots to Old High German, in Italian interpretations it can be associated with â€œaffectionateâ€.

Felice â€“ Though more associated with â€œhappinessâ€, love and joy often intertwine. In Italian, it means â€œhappyâ€ or â€œfortunateâ€.

Nature-Inspired

Bosco â€“ Meaning â€œforestâ€ or â€œwoodsâ€.

Cielo â€“ Meaning â€œskyâ€.

Gemma â€“ Meaning â€œgemâ€ or â€œprecious stoneâ€.

Nives â€“ Derived from Latin, meaning â€œsnowâ€.

Virtue-Inspired

Grazia â€“ Meaning â€œgraceâ€ or â€œfavorâ€, suggesting elegance and kindness.

Allegria â€“ Meaning â€œjoyâ€ or â€œhappinessâ€.

Fede â€“ Meaning â€œfaithâ€.

Speranza â€“ Meaning â€œhopeâ€.

Prudenza â€“ Meaning â€œprudenceâ€ or â€œcautionâ€, signifying wisdom.

Pazienza â€“ Meaning â€œpatienceâ€.

UmiltÃ  â€“ Meaning â€œhumilityâ€.

Amore â€“ Meaning â€œloveâ€.

Fortuna â€“ Meaning â€œfortuneâ€ or â€œluckâ€, but in a virtuous context it can suggest blessings.

Lealta â€“ Meaning â€œloyaltyâ€.

Benedetta â€“ Derived from â€œbenedettoâ€, meaning â€œblessedâ€.

Onesta â€“ Meaning â€œhonestyâ€.

Saggezza â€“ Meaning â€œwisdomâ€.

VirtÃ¹ â€“ Directly translates to â€œvirtueâ€.

Names Meaning Joy or Happiness

Letizia â€“ Meaning â€œjoyâ€ or â€œhappiness.â€

Felicia â€“ Derived from the word â€œfelice,â€ meaning â€œhappyâ€ or â€œfortunate.â€

Gioia â€“ Meaning â€œjoy.â€

Remember, names can carry deep cultural and familial significance, so some of these names might be chosen not just for their direct meanings but also for the broader sentiments they evoke.

Star or Moon-inspired

Stellina â€“ Meaning â€œlittle star.â€

Luna â€“ Meaning â€œmoon.â€

What Are The Most Popular Italian Girl Names?

Italyâ€™s esteemed Institute for Statistics, popularly known as Istat, has been a reliable source for understanding the trends in baby names.

Every year, Istat diligently publishes a list showcasing the most popular names chosen by new parents in Italy (so no, not in the US)!

While these lists provide a fascinating insight into naming trends in Italy, itâ€™s worth noting that the most recent data available is for children born in 2021.

For the ease of our readers, weâ€™ve compiled this list below, and added the meaning to each name.

Bottom Line

We hope youâ€™ve found the perfect name for your baby girl within our extensive collection of Italian girl names. If not, know that this list is an ongoing project.

Weâ€™re committed to periodically revisiting and enriching it with more categories and names to ensure you have the most comprehensive options. Stay tuned for updates! Ciao!

PS. Not sure if itâ€™s going to be a baby girl? Why not go through the list of Italian boy names, just in case, of course ğŸ™‚

PS.PS. Thinking about getting a furry friend? Check out our Italian dog names collection to find him or her a perfect name.
